transcript:
Patient: Some of the tools that have been most helpful for me are the thought records and the 3C's technique. I think those will be important for me to keep using, even after our sessions end.

Therapist: I agree, Alejandro. The thought records and 3C's technique are powerful tools for managing negative thoughts and building more balanced perspectives. Another strategy we can add to your toolbox is creating coping cards with personalized affirmations and reminders of your new, adaptive beliefs. These can be helpful to carry with you and refer to when you need a boost. What are some affirmations or reminders that you think would be most helpful for you?

Patient: I like the idea of coping cards. Some affirmations that come to mind are "Progress, not perfection" and "I am enough, just as I am." Those feel really meaningful to me.

Therapist: Those are wonderful affirmations, Alejandro. They capture the essence of the new beliefs we've been working on building - that your worth is not tied to perfection, and that you are inherently valuable and worthy, just as you are. We can create coping cards with those affirmations, along with some reminders of the skills and strategies you've found most helpful, like the 3C's technique. That way, you'll have a tangible reminder of the progress you've made and the tools you have to support yourself going forward.

Patient: That sounds really helpful. I also think it will be important for me to have a plan for how to access support from others, like you mentioned. I know my sister will always be there for me, but sometimes it's hard for me to reach out.

Therapist: That's a great point, Alejandro. Having a strong support system is crucial for maintaining your progress and managing any challenges that may arise. It's okay if it feels hard to reach out sometimes - that's normal. We can brainstorm some strategies to make it easier, like scheduling regular check-ins with your sister, or even just sending a quick text when you need a little extra support. Another option to consider is joining a support group for people who have gone through similar experiences. That can be a great way to connect with others who understand what you're going through and can offer encouragement and understanding. What are your thoughts on that?

Patient: I've never really considered a support group before, but I can see how it could be helpful. It would be nice to know I'm not alone in this.

Therapist: Absolutely. Support groups can be a powerful reminder that you're not alone, and that recovery is possible. Of course, it's totally up to you whether that feels like a good fit for you. The most important thing is that you have a plan for how to access support when you need it, whether that's from your sister, a support group, or even periodic "booster" sessions with a therapist if needed. We can work together to create a personalized support plan that feels right for you.

Patient: That sounds good. I feel like having a plan will help me feel more confident about maintaining my progress after our sessions end.

Therapist: I'm so glad to hear that, Alejandro. You've made incredible progress in our work together, and I have full confidence in your ability to continue using the skills and tools you've learned. Remember, recovery is a journey, and there may be ups and downs along the way. The key is to keep practicing, keep reaching out for support when you need it, and keep believing in yourself. You have all the tools and strengths you need to keep moving forward.
